text: was an old province of Japan in the area of Hyōgo Prefecture on the island of Honshū.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Tajima" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 930. It was sometimes called . The province had borders with Harima, Inaba, Tamba, and Tango provinces. The ancient provincial capital city was near Hidaka. ==History== In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. The maps of Japan and Tajima Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. ==Shrines and Temples== Izushi jinja was the chief Shinto shrine (ichinomiya) of Tajima."Nationwide List of Ichinomiya," p. 2 ; retrieved 2012-1-17. ==Related pages== * Provinces of Japan * Prefectures of Japan * List of regions of Japan * List of islands of Japan ==References== ==Other websites == * Murdoch's map of provinces, 1903 Category:Former provinces of Japan Category:Hyōgo Prefecture
